 1.) What premise or philosophy drives your utopia?
 2.) What kind of political government would you have? Monarchy, Democracy, Republic, Aristocracy? 
 3.) What financial system would drive your society? Capitalism, socialism, a mixture? 
 4.) How would your protect your utopia?
 5.) Summarize why it would work.

I am interested in society structures and what drives them. My approach to society and philosophy is driven by the empiricisms and schemas of such philosophers as Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, David Hume, and of course Marx.
 
 Premise
 The premise of my utopia is to provide everyone with the best possible life they could have. My primary concern is the comfort and protection of the people. 
 
 
 Government Politics 
 I would design a government that is partially Republic and Aristocracy. The people elect a sovereign as their voice. The sovereign controls the military and has primary power. He would be backed by a parliament that controls all other government functions and keeps him in check. The parliament elects its own officials. 
 
 
 Financial Politics
 My financial policy is predominantly social with capitalist endeavors. It has three basic parts: Government controlled, government sanctioned, and private industry. 
 
 Government controlled: Basically, the government controls all basic necessities of its people. Food, water, shelter, transportation, education, sanitation, energy, and medical care. Government employees do not make large wages, and their wages are paid by difficulty of profession, however all of their necessities are provided. The government controls so many resources that there should never be shortage of work.
 
 Government sanctioned: Private investors sponsored by the government. They are granted government aid in return for service treaties and goods.
 
 Private industries: Entertainment, fasion, advanced living, realestate, technology, recreation, advanced transportation, etc. All private industries run independent of the government. Private industry owners and employees do not receive government support for basic necessities. Therefore, wages must be much greater than the government could provide.
 
 The nice part about the system is that it allows two options for finding comfort: Those people who want to live on the government, and those who want to satisfy their drive for success. If you fail in one, you can always switch back to the other, and infact, is encouraged to get ahead. The system gives everyone a chance. This also means that government controlled industries will always be fairly maintained and quality of goods and services will always remain static. And private industries, in turn, can do whatever the hell they like.
 
 
 Protection
 The utopia is protected externally by its military, lead by the sovereign. It is internally protected by police and law officials appointed by the parliament. The parliament sustains the people, and without its functions, the society would fail. This is what keeps the sovereign in check. The basic principle is more about autonomy. Abuse of power can be checked one way or the other.

 A communist is a Marxist. A communist wishes to abolish the exploitation of man by man. He wants to do this by first abolishing private property over the means of production and giving power to the people (therefore establishing a socialist system), then slowly phasing out even personal property and the State itself, until communism is achieved. Communism is a classless, propertyless, stateless social system organized along the principle "from each, according to his ability; to each, according to his needs". 
 
 An anarchist is someone who wishes to establish communism virtually overnight, without going through any intermediary socialist stage. Anarchists call for the immediate abolition of the state and all private property. 
 
 A socialist is a person who supports a socialist system - in other words, a system of public ownership over the means of production, with a planned economy and a democratic state - but without wishing for that system to eventually turn into a communist one. A socialist wants to abolish private property over the means of production, but maintain personal property and the state. A socialist wants to reduce inequality to a minimum, but not remove it entirely. 
 
 A social democrat is someone who wants to combine socialism with capitalism. Social democrats believe they are taking the "best" elements of both socialism and capitalism and using them together to create a "mixed economy" (also known as a welfare state). 
 
 A centrist or moderate is a person who doesn't really hold any political views, and simply chooses whatever option seems best to him/her at one particular time. 
 
 A liberal is someone who supports capitalism (private property over the means of production) but wants people to have freedom of choice in personal matters. 
 
 A conservative is someone who supports capitalism (private property over the means of production) and also supports rigid "traditional values" in personal matters. 
 
 A nationalist is a person who puts his or her nation above anything else, who blindly supports his nation regardless of whether it is right or wrong, and who believes in strict hierarchy and obedience. 
 
 A fascist is someone who has a burning hatred for democracy, human rights, and all forms of equality. A fascist supports dictatorship, an even more strict hierarchy than that of the nationalists, and brutal treatment of political opponents. Fascists despise all workers' movements (particularly communists) and are often (but not always) virulently racist.

 What, you want to phase out personal property? That is a direct assault on the liberty of the worker, I say.
 
 The domain of property has its place, just as the domain of self-ownership and the common domain have their places. Specifically, property and the absence thereof is justified by the right to work, which can be divided into two rights:
 
 < The right to initiate any undertaking without requiring anyone else's permission, so long as doing so does not violate the individual right to self-ownership or:
 
 < The right to continue an undertaking without unwanted interference from other individuals.
 
 These in turn derive their justification from the right, as Jefferson put it, to pursue happiness.
 
 The initiation of an undertaking is the harvesting of a resource - in order to grow a plant, someone must first pick a seed from another plant, and in order to build a car, someone must mine the metals needed to build a car, and so on.
 
 Individual property therefore justly exists over the resources which he has harvested from Nature. Thus he can control his undertaking, and modify his resources as he will, and produce a final product, which in turn he may own as well. But if property rights go so far as to restrict the harvesting of resources from Nature, they violate the first component of the right to work - the right to initiate work.
 
 I make the distinction between "regal property" and "personal property." Regal property is the ownership of unharvested resources; namely, land ownership. Regal property is unjust - unharvested resources ought to be accessible to all. Personal property is the ownership of harvested resources and anything produced from them. This is justified when the resources are initially owned by the individuals who harvest them. Personal property may be owned individually or shared voluntarily, not to mention exchanged in a free market. It is wrong to assert that all undertakings must be lone individual efforts, just as it is wrong to assert that all undertakings must be mass collective efforts.
